question: It's a relaxing evening, and you're considering a beverage. What sounds best? (A) A glass of robust Cabernet Sauvignon. (B) A cup of herbal tea.
We're celebrating a special occasion tonight! What drink would be most fitting? (A) A bottle of fine Champagne or a celebrated Bordeaux. (B) Perhaps some sparkling cider or a craft soda.
When considering a sophisticated accompaniment to a rich cheese platter, what comes to mind? (A) A well-paired Port wine or a crisp Sauvignon Blanc. (B) Maybe some artisanal crackers and fruit juice.

Someone asks for your opinion on the best way to unwind after a long week. (A) Exploring a new wine varietal can be a delightful experience. (B) Catching up on a good book with any simple beverage is fine.

When asked about your interest in oenology (the study of wine), how might you respond? (A) I find the complexity and history of winemaking quite fascinating. (B) It's not a subject I've given much thought to; I prefer simpler hobbies.

If you were to describe the experience of tasting a high-quality, aged red wine: (A) It offers a complex bouquet of aromas and a rich tapestry of flavors on the palate. (B) It tastes like grape juice, but stronger and sometimes a bit sour.

A friend is looking for a gift for a dinner party host who enjoys fine beverages. (A) A bottle of well-regarded wine from a good vintage is usually a safe and appreciated choice. (B) A box of chocolates or a nice tea selection would be thoughtful.

When you sit down at a nice restaurant, what's one of the first things you consider? (A) I'll peruse the wine list for interesting options or good pairings. (B) I'll check the daily food specials immediately.

You're planning a meal with a distinctive main course. What's a key thought regarding beverages? (A) Which type of wine would best complement and enhance the flavors of this dish? (B) As long as there's something to drink, the specific pairing isn't a major concern.
There's an opportunity to attend a local event this weekend. Which sounds more appealing? (A) A guided wine tasting session featuring regional specialties. (B) A screening of a popular new movie.

At a casual get-together, your host offers you a choice between a craft beer and a glass of pleasant red wine. (A) The craft beer sounds good right now. (B) A glass of red wine would be lovely, thank you.
You're ordering pasta with a rich tomato-based sauce. What drink do you request? (A) I'll just have a glass of water, please. (B) A classic Chianti or a medium-bodied red wine would be perfect.

If you were to spend an afternoon learning about a type of beverage in detail, which topic would you pick? (A) Advanced coffee brewing techniques and bean roasting profiles. (B) The impact of terroir and climate on different grape varietals.

You need to buy a gift for someone who appreciates fine consumables. What's your first idea? (A) A high-quality set of artisanal jams or a gourmet food basket. (B) A bottle of wine from a reputable producer or an interesting wine accessory.

When discussing food and drink, what kind of flavor profiles do you generally gravitate towards? (A) I tend to prefer simpler, more straightforward tastes that are easy to identify. (B) I enjoy exploring complex and nuanced flavors, like those found in well-aged wines or intricate dishes.

After a satisfying dinner, what kind of beverage might you consider to round off the meal? (A) A cup of decaffeinated coffee or a herbal infusion. (B) A small glass of dessert wine, like a Sauternes or a Port.

You're invited to a potluck dinner. What are you most likely to contribute? (A) I'll prepare a homemade casserole or a fresh salad. (B) I'll pick up a versatile bottle of wine that pairs well with a variety of foods.

If you had some leisure time for reading, which publication would you choose? (A) A bestselling fiction novel or a current affairs magazine. (B) A journal dedicated to wine regions, vineyard profiles, and tasting notes.

When friends are discussing their hobbies, what might you share an interest in? (A) I'm quite passionate about hiking and outdoor photography. (B) I've recently started exploring the world of wine, perhaps even collecting a few interesting bottles.

You're packing a basket for a picnic on a sunny afternoon. What beverage is essential? (A) A large thermos of iced tea or fresh lemonade is always a crowd-pleaser. (B) A chilled bottle of rosé or a crisp white wine would be perfect for the occasion.

You're planning a sophisticated dinner party for friends. What's a primary consideration for beverages? (A) I'll curate a thoughtful wine selection, perhaps with different options for each course or to suit various preferences. (B) I'll just buy a large assortment of sodas, juices, and maybe one type of generic beer.

If you visit a country renowned for its historic vineyards, what activity would be high on your list? (A) I'd definitely want to tour a few local wineries and learn about their production methods. (B) I'm more interested in visiting the major historical landmarks and museums in the cities.

For a romantic dinner at home, what beverage choice helps create a special atmosphere? (A) Opening a carefully chosen bottle of wine that you both enjoy. (B) Just serving whatever drinks happen to be readily available in the refrigerator.

At a gathering, the only alcoholic option presented with enthusiasm is a house wine you suspect isn't great. What's your thought? (A) I'm open to trying it; sometimes house wines can be a pleasant surprise. (B) I'll probably stick to a non-alcoholic drink or water tonight.

When hosting a multi-course dinner, how do you approach drink pairings? (A) I think about selecting specific wines that will complement and elevate each dish. (B) Providing one or two all-purpose beverage options for the entire meal is simplest.

If asked about your general beverage preferences for an organized event or function: (A) I generally enjoy trying different wines if they are offered as an option. (B) I'm quite easy to please; any standard non-alcoholic beverage is perfectly fine for me.

A friend expresses interest in learning more about wine but feels overwhelmed. What advice might you offer? (A) Suggest they start with a comparative tasting of a few common varietals to understand basic differences. (B) Tell them it's probably too complicated a hobby and not really worth the effort unless they're serious.

You're looking for a new culinary adventure or experience. Which of these sounds more appealing? (A) Exploring food and wine pairings from a specific, lesser-known international region. (B) Trying out a new trendy fusion restaurant that focuses on unusual ingredient combinations.

If attending a business lunch where it's appropriate to have an alcoholic beverage, what might you choose? (A) A light, crisp white wine, if it seems suitable for the professional setting and meal. (B) Iced tea or sparkling water is always a safe and appropriate choice for business lunches.

What are your thoughts on the practice of cellaring or aging wines? (A) It seems like a fascinating way to observe how flavors can evolve and mature over time. (B) It appears to be a lot of unnecessary hassle and expense for just a beverage.

At a summer barbecue, the drink options include standard beers, various sodas, and a surprisingly good-looking bottle of Zinfandel someone brought. (A) A cold beer is the classic choice for a barbecue. (B) That Zinfandel looks quite intriguing; I'd like to try a glass of that.

When considering what to drink with a particularly spicy dish, what comes to mind? (A) Milk or a yogurt-based drink like lassi is often recommended to cool the palate. (B) An off-dry Riesling or a Gewürztraminer could offer a complementary sweetness and aromatic profile.

You read a news article discussing the potential health benefits of moderate consumption of different beverages. Which finding piques your interest more? (A) The article focuses on the antioxidant properties and cognitive benefits associated with regular green tea consumption. (B) The article highlights studies suggesting cardiovascular benefits from the polyphenols found in red wine.

If you were to join a gourmet club, which thematic focus would be more appealing? (A) Exploring the art of artisan bread making and sourdough cultures. (B) Delving into the distinctions between Old World and New World wines through comparative tastings.

When someone mentions the term 'terroir' in a conversation about food or drink: (A) I would politely ask for a clarification, as the term isn't immediately familiar to me. (B) I understand it to refer to the unique environmental factors—like soil, climate, and topography—that influence a wine's character.

A friend is feeling stressed and looking for a way to unwind. What might you suggest? (A) Recommend they go for a brisk walk or engage in some light physical activity to clear their head. (B) Suggest they prepare a comforting meal and enjoy it with a glass of their favorite wine in a relaxing setting.

While planning a vacation itinerary for a region known for its wine production, what takes priority? (A) Focusing on visiting historical sites, museums, and natural landmarks in the area. (B) Ensuring the schedule includes visits to renowned vineyards, cellar tours, and tasting experiences.

A companion at dinner seems intimidated by the extensive wine list. How might you help? (A) Suggest they just pick the second cheapest option, as it's usually decent. (B) Encourage them to describe what they usually like or what they're eating, then offer to help choose or suggest asking the sommelier.

If you had to choose one type of complex beverage to study deeply and become an expert in: (A) The world of single-origin coffees, from bean cultivation to brewing methods. (B) The diverse and historic wines produced in the Burgundy region of France.

You're preparing a light seafood dish, perhaps grilled fish or shrimp. What's a good beverage pairing? (A) A tall glass of fresh lemonade or iced tea would be refreshing. (B) A crisp, dry white wine like a Pinot Grigio or Sauvignon Blanc would complement it beautifully.
